column1: The CPU is the Central Processing Unit, and it is the brain" of the computer that carries out calculations."
The CPU is the Core Power Unit, and it is the heart" of the computer that circulates energy."
Main memory, often referred to as RAM, is where the computer stores data and programs while they are being used.
Main memory, often referred to as ROM, is where the computer stores data and programs while they are being used.
Volatile memory requires power to maintain the stored information, and loses its contents when the power is turned off.
Non-volatile memory requires power to maintain the stored information, and loses its contents when the power is turned off.
Hard drives and solid-state drives are examples of non-volatile storage that retain data even when power is lost.
Hard drives and solid-state drives are examples of volatile storage that lose data when power is lost.
The Arithmetic Logic Unit (ALU) is responsible for performing arithmetic and logical operations in the CPU.
The Arithmetic Logic Unit (ALU) is responsible for directing the flow of data within the CPU.
The Control Unit acts as a manager, coordinating and controlling the actions of other hardware components in the CPU.
The Control Unit acts as a calculator, performing all arithmetic and logical operations in the CPU.
The fetch-decode-execute cycle is the fundamental process by which a CPU executes instructions.
The fetch-decode-execute cycle is the fundamental process by which a CPU stores data in memory.
In the fetch stage of the CPU cycle, the instruction is retrieved from memory.
In the execute stage of the CPU cycle, the instruction is retrieved from memory.
Binary is a base-2 number system used by digital devices, consisting of only two digits: 0 and 1.
Hexadecimal is a base-2 number system used by digital devices, consisting of only two digits: 0 and 1.
Hexadecimal is a base-16 number system, utilizing digits from 0 to 9 and letters from A to F.
Octal is a base-16 number system, utilizing digits from 0 to 9 and letters from A to F.
Input refers to data or signals received by the computer for processing.
Output refers to data or signals received by the computer for processing.
Output is the results produced by the computer after data processing.
Input is the results produced by the computer after data processing.
An interrupt is a signal to the processor indicating an event needing immediate attention.
Polling is a signal to the processor indicating an event needing immediate attention.
Polling is a method whereby the computer regularly checks the status of an input/output device to see if it's ready for data transfer.
An interrupt is a method whereby the computer regularly checks the status of an input/output device to see if it's ready for data transfer.
The operating system is software that manages hardware resources, provides services for software applications, and acts as an interface between the user and the hardware.
